title: 111_s3009
content: The Act may be cited as the "1863 Gettysburg Campaign Act". The Congress acknowledges the significance of the 1863 invasion of Pennsylvania and the Battle of Gettysburg in the American Civil War. President Abraham Lincoln's Gettysburg Address highlighted the war's importance in relation to the American Revolution. The Army Heritage Center Foundation collaborates with the United States Army to maintain the United States Army Heritage and Education Center in Carlisle, Pennsylvania, known for its exceptional Civil War collection. The Army Heritage Center Foundation (AHCF) aims to honor soldiers' service and sacrifice, preserve their memories through artifact collections, and educate the public. The AHCF also funds the construction of the Army Heritage Museum and Visitor and Education Center, focusing on providing support for educational programs. The AHCF and the Gettysburg Foundation provide support for educational programs and activities at the AHEC and Gettysburg National Military Park, including operating museums, preserving resources, and educating visitors about the significance of historical events. The Gettysburg Foundation and AHCF are non-profit organizations that support the Gettysburg National Military Park and Army Heritage and Education Center. The Gettysburg Foundation is the official partner of the park, while AHCF is recognized as the lead agency supporting the development of the AHEC. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury shall mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins in recognition of the 1863 Invasion of Pennsylvania, the Battle of Gettysburg, and President Lincoln's Gettysburg Address. The Secretary of the Treasury shall mint and issue half dollar clad coins weighing 11.34 grams with a diameter of 1.205 inches, minted to specific specifications. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall commemorate the Battle of Gettysburg and President Lincoln's Gettysburg Address with specific motifs. The coins will also feature inscriptions of the coin's value, the year "2013", and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary after consultation. The design of the coins minted under this Act will commemorate the Battle of Gettysburg and President Lincoln's Gettysburg Address. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with various entities and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5 of the Act specifies that coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities using US Mint facilities, and the Secretary can only issue these coins within a 1-year period starting from January 1, 2013. SEC. 6 of the Act outlines the sale of coins, including pricing details and bulk sales. The Secretary can accept prepaid orders at a discount before issuing the coins. All sales of coins minted under this Act include surcharges: $35 for the $5 coin, $10 for the $1 coin, and $5 for the half dollar coin. Surcharges are distributed to the Gettysburg Foundation and AHCF to finance their programs. The Foundation and AHCF are subject to audit requirements for the amounts received. No surcharge may be included for the issuance of any coin under this Act. The Secretary may issue guidance to limit the number of commemorative coin programs issued in a calendar year to avoid exceeding the annual issuance limitation.
